Finally, the details of both facility and equipment design are key to the safe operations of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems.
i.	Facility Design
The plant and support equipment of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage and control buildings meet and exceed design codes standards and good engineering practices. The buildings are equipped with ambient ventilation storage area and a fan ventilated control room.
ii.	Equipment Design
The low pressure chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems operate under a vacuum pressure of 13 inches of mercury. All the pipe, tubes, and equipment are chlorine- and sulfur dioxide-compatible nonmetallic piping. The system is designed with a safety factor covering the typical vacuum pressure in it. There are monitors that detect the presence of chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide in the storage building rooms. 5.	REGULATED SUBSTANCES 
Chlorine and sulfur dioxide are the only regulated substances on-site which exceed the 40 CFR 68 threshold quantities. The COAB chlorine and dechlorination processes were installed as part of the process of treating wastewater to meet strict FDEP discharge permit requirements.  The facility operates under permit from the State of Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FDEP). The chlorine and sulfur dioxide are received, stored and distributed to two process control systems.  

Chlorine is an EPA and OSHA-listed toxic chemical. It is an irritant and it is corrosive. Chlorine is a halogen with the formula Cl2. It is a chlorinating or oxidizing agent that is not flammable. It has a 1 ppm OSHA ceiling Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) and a NFPA health rating of 4, severe; with immediate and delayed health hazards. Chlorine is not a carcinogen.  

Sulfur dioxide is an EPA-and OSHA-listed toxic chemical.  It is an irritant and it is corrosive.  Sulfur dioxide is a gas or liquid under pressure with the formula S02.  It is a dechlorinating or oxidizing agent that is not flammable.  It has a 5 ppm OSHA PEL and a NFPA health rating of 4, severe; with immediate and delayed health hazards.  S

8.	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 
The City of Atlantic Beach Water Plant #1 had no accidental releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide in the past five years per 40 CFR 67.42 (a).

9.	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
Emergency response procedures are described in the City of Atlantic Beach Emergency Response Plan.  Emergency phone numbers are posted at each facility, indicating who to call first and what to do if that person is unreachable. The Jacksonville Fire Department (911) is the first call listed.  The Plant also has site specific emergency actions defined in the plant operating procedures. Emergency response drills and drill evaluations are conducted annually by the operating department. Emergency operation and response procedures are reviewed and updated based on the results of the drill.

The emergency response program is reviewed by the Jacksonville Fire Department, which coordinates with local Duval County Emergency Response Planning Committee (LEPC) and Jacksonville Fire Department HazMat Team, all located in Duval County, Florida. Copies of the program are given to key local agencies including the fire, medical, rescue, management, and police departments in Atlantic Beach. Besides the specific emergency response program, key elements of the prevention programs are incorporated in the operating culture of the City of Atlantic Beach WTP # 1.

The Contingency Plan procedures detail the actions and responses to chlorine and sulfur dioxide spills (releases). The plan includes training of all chlorination and dechlorination-area operators. The primary response team is the Jacksonville Fire and Rescue, plus the HazMat Team, who respond to severe leak situations. A Chlorine B Leak Repair Kit is maintained on site to aid in stopping leaks. Public notification is facilitated through the Atlantic Beach Police Department, which has an automated emergency dialing message system for public notification.

7.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 
The COAB Accidental Release Prevention Program is based on the OSHA PSM Standard.  Since the facility is a public owned entity, it is subject to the EPA RMP Level 2 Prevention Program. The COAB Prevention Program has been in place and effectively used since the RMP rule was promulgated. It is part of the plants operating culture. There are two parts to the program. The first is the general overall City wide and WWTP #1 site program. The second is the chlorine-specific actions within the site program coordinated with the City of Jacksonville Fire Department.

The City of Atlantic Beach (COAB) Public Works Department operates the COAB Wastewater                           Treatment Plant (WWTP) #1 located at 1100 Sandpiper Lane, Atlantic Beach, Duval Country, Florida. This plant is one of five water and wastewater plants operated by COAB. WWTP #1 and three other plants have quantities of regulated hazardous chemicals above the EPA threshold. COAB has a unified Risk Management Program which applies to each plant. Only WWTP # 1 operations and policies are presented in this Plan.

1.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 
The City of Atlantic Beach (COAB), Florida, Water Treatment Plant (WTP) #1 Accidental Release Prevention Program involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures and management practices. The prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR 68.

2.	MANAGEMENT SYSTEM 
COAB has a management system in place which is led by the Deputy Public Works Director, who oversees the implementation and on-going use of the RMP elements. This program, along with other City-wide and plant-specific policies, eliminates and /or reduces the likelihood of a hazardous chemical release at the plant.

3.	PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 2 
COAB maintains policies, procedures, and systems as part of their prevention program. These are applied to WWTP #1 and each COAB treatment plant. The COAB program addresses each of the elements needed to implement the EPA RMP Program Level 2, which are also addressed in the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program. Being a public entity, COAB is subject to only the EPA RMP Level 2 Prevention Program. The policies and procedures are maintained in the COAB Document Management System (DMS).

6.	WORST AND ALTERNATIVE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS 
Two offsite consequence analyses were conducted which include two chlorine release scenarios, since chlorine has the lower PEL.  A sulfur dioxide release would have similar consequences.  

The first is a worst case release. The second is a more probable alternative release scenario. The first scenario is defined by EPA, which states that the ... shall assume that the ... maximum quantity in the largest vessel ... is released as a gas over 10 minutes due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined as more likely to occur than the worst case scenario.  An atmospheric dispersion assessment was performed to determine the distance traveled by the chlorine released before its concentration decreases to the toxic endpoint. The EPA-selected endpoint for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/l or  3 parts per million (ppm). The 3 ppm endpoint is the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG- 2). This is defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action. The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance was defined, to estimate the population potentially affected.
